title: How correct is this sentence, 'Now silence gone as death'? - Quora

response.answer_text: If silence is gone, then there is no silence. Silence that goes away becomes noise. Silence and death are related, as one who has died is silent. You need a verb to make this into a sentence, and I am not sure if ‘gone’ is the right verb. What are you trying to say? That silence is like death? That silence has become as still as death? (Still meaning having no movement or sound). Are you composing a poem? Now silence has gone still as death…but silence has always been the ‘going away of sound’—no sound. I am a bit confused.

The spelling of the words in the sentence is correct. However, the sentence is missing a verb and possibly some other words as well. I can’t tell what this sentence is trying to say, so I can’t tell you how to correct it.
